h3. Issue Summary

If the user set the language on one Code Block macro and click into an another it will show the language as in prior Code Block macro.

Now if the user clicks elsewhere else, and then click again on the later code block it won't have any language set. So the user has to click into and click out each one in order to check if they have the right language set.
h3. Environment


 * Cloud Confluence
 *
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create 2 Code Block Macro in the same Page. Set a language for the first macro.
 # Click on 2nd macro, it will show the language set as in prior Code Block macro.
 # Click out of the Macro then again click on the Macro.

h3. Expected Results

The language should be the same language as of the 1st macro or it should be blank, instead of fluctuating in between.
h3. Actual Results

The language fluctuates(same as 1st macro or blank).

 
h3. Workaround

Manually set the language of the 2nd macro.

Confluence Server [has the ability to stick table headers in view mode|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/tables-136463.html?_ga=2.263428172.1756890740.1563174245-1999825829.1533742022#Tables-stickytableheadersStickytableheadersinviewmode] when tables get too large on a page.

It makes longer tables easier to read.

 !ImportScreen.png|thumbnail!

 !PageTreeAfter.png|thumbnail!

Confluence Cloud

 # Create a parent page with a few child pages.
 # Create a Word document that has the same name as the parent page you created.

 # Navigate to one of the deleted pages, you will see *Page Not Found*.

The sidebar page tree should automatically be updated to reflect those changes.
 
h3. Actual Results
Former page tree is cached, updates do not reflect changes.

h3. Notes

If you were to include headings and choose *Split by heading* then the pages are split into child pages as expected, and the broken links are repaired.

h3. Workaround
Manually delete child pages

On [this article|https://confluence.atlassian.com/confcloud/insert-links-and-anchors-724764900.html#InsertLinksandAnchors-Linktoanundefinedpage(apagethatdoesnotexistyet)undefinedpages] we have a cool functionality on Confluence that is only available on the old editing experience.

* {{https://SITE_NAME.atlassian.net/wiki/pages/createpage.action?spaceKey=SPACEKEY}}

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Jira macros in Confluence are not handling well Next-gen issue statuses.

Example of JQL in Jira:
{code:java}
project = A or project = B where status = 'TO DO'
{code}
Say, this JQL shows 8 issues in TO DO (4 from project A and 4 from project B)

When you save this JQL and use for Confluence macro like _Issue statistics_ or _Two dimensional Filter statistics_, the following happens:
 * If both projects are classic, then we are gonna see 1 TO DO column in macro showing 8 issues.
 * If one of the projects is next-gen, then we are gonna see two columns with TO DO, each showing 4.
 * If both projects are next-gen, then we are gonna see two columns with TO DO, each showing 4.

Issuetype IDs are always different for next-gen projects, even though name "TO DO" is the same. JQL in Jira handles it well and shows total 8 issues without any differentiation.

So we have a discrepancy between JQL in Jira and any Confluence macro.
 Filing a bug, JAC is not responding at the moment.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create 2 Next-gen projects in Jira
 # Create at least one issue having the same status and issue type for each project
 # Use JQL in Jira like:
{code:java}
project = A or project = B
{code}
It will show you total of 2 issues.

 # Create _Issue statistics_ macro in Confluence and use the same JQL

h3. Expected Results

We should see output of 2 issues in one column if sorting is by status and status of both issues is the same
h3. Actual Results

Even if issue type and status of issues is the same, there will be two separate columns for each "TO DO" status.

!image-2019-07-10-12-10-18-159.png|width=522,height=162!

We should see the same result as JQL in Jira.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior.
fields.summary: Jira macros are not showing the same results for Next-gen projects as JQL in Jira

h3. Issue Summary

When integrating Jira and Confluence, if a Jira issue macro is mentioned on the page, the same will have the Confluence page displayed in the "*mentioned in*" section. However, when importing issues from CSV that had the same key from an existing project in the current Jira, and also, importing the related space with the existing issue, the *mentioned in* section will not display the Confluence page.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

Have two Confluence and Jira instances to perform the migration.

h5.Jira and Confluence A

# Make sure to create one or more issues in the instance A
# Now, in Confluence, make sure to create a space with a page that will be including the Jira issues, so it will populate the "mentioned in" section with the Confluence page.
# In Confluence, make sure to go to *Space Settings > Content Tools > Export > XML* so the space with the Jira issue will be exported.
# In Jira, use the search from Jira in order to populate the result with the created issues and export the same to CSV (used the *Current fields* option on the tests) and download the CSV.

h5.Jira and Confluence B

# Now, in this Jira, make sure to create a new project using the same key and name from the Jira instance A
# Use the *External System import* tool in order to import the CSV from Jira A into the newly created project with the same key
# In Confluence B, make sure to use the *import spaces* option from the administration in order to import the recently exported space from Confluence A.
# Make sure to reload the page, or, re-insert the Jira issue.

h3. Expected Results
The "*mentioned in*" section should populate with the linked Confluence page.

h3. Actual Results
The "*mentioned in*" section does not populate with the page.

h3. Notes

* The Jira links count is not displayed in the Confluence page(s)
* The Jira macro repair will not help on the issue to be fixed.
* Re-inserting the Jira macro will not work.

The results will also depend on small details like if the issue/page were created after the migration. For example, the following has been observed:

||Jira issue created|Confluence page created|Results||
|After migration|After migration|(/)|
|After migration|before migration|(/)|
|Before migration|After migration|(/)|
|before migration|before migration|(x)|

h3. Workaround

Edit the page in order to remove the Jira macro and publish it. After that, make sure to edit the page again so the macro can be re-inserted, and then, publish it. Using a different key in the newly created project in instance B will also help on not triggering the bug.
fields.summary: Migrating Jira projects with the same key will affect linked pages from Confluence

h3. Summary
Copying pages with images using [Copy page hierarchy|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/confluence/rest/#api-content-id-pagehierarchy-copy-post] REST API results in broken images to destination pages.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new page with the fabric editor
# Insert an image via upload
# Copy the page using the [Copy page hierarchy|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/confluence/rest/#api-content-id-pagehierarchy-copy-post] REST API
# Go to the copied page
# Observe that the image is not displayed

h3. Expected Results
Images and other attachments are rendered properly.

h3. Actual Results 
Images are blank/broken.

h3. Notes 
* The attachments are successfully copied with the pages in the tree, but do not render when the page is viewed.
* Editing the page and trying to publish it again causes a generic error flag to be displayed.  Inspecting the error detail in the dev console shows a 400 error when PUTting the ADF data for the page.
* If you view the storage format xml (sfxml) for the copied page, you will notice the following structure for the image:

{code:xml}
<ac:image ac:align="center" ac:layout="center" ac:original-height="667" ac:original-width="500">
  <ri:attachment ri:filename="keep-crom.jpg" ri:version-at-save="1">
    <ri:page ri:space-key="CPTITO" ri:content-title="[COPY] Attachments" ri:version-at-save="2" />
  </ri:attachment>
</ac:image>
{code}
This structure works perfectly using the old editor, but appears to be incompatible with fabric-editor pages.  Note that the <ri:page> element's space-key and title values are trivial, as they are rewritten to refer to the same space and page.  Also note that attempting to publish this sfxml structure to a fabric-editor page using a PUT on the /content REST API results in a 400 error whose description is simply an UnsupportedOperationException.  Judging by the fact that the fabric editor inexplicably no longer supports inserting attachments from other spaces and pages, I am not entirely surprised by this, and believe it is likely an incompatibility between sfxml's superior feature set over what the new ADF format supports.

Normally, old-editor pages displaying images from the same space and page omit that ri:page element, simply looking like this:

{code:xml}
<ac:image ac:align="center" ac:layout="center" ac:original-height="667" ac:original-width="500">
  <ri:attachment ri:filename="keep-crom.jpg" ri:version-at-save="1" />
</ac:image>
{code}


h3. Workaround 
None so far.
fields.summary: Copy page hierarchy REST API does not handle attachments properly for fabric editor pages
